text: I pretend to follow, but stop at the last step of the stairs—something about this place feels wrong. I want to see it more clearly.
“Wait. Let me take a look at the formation.”
“Don’t—!” Lucia instinctively reaches out to pull me back.
I still take a step forward.
The moment my boot touches that dark blue line, the ground reacts—as if something has ‘heard’ it—
With a low hum, the fading formation flares to life for an instant.
Cold shoots up from my ankle. My vision blurs, and in my ears it feels like someone is whispering the same sentence over and over.
“…What—”
When the chill recedes from my ankle, something rolls off the sole of my boot.
“…What is this?”
It’s a small shard of dark blue crystal, a flicker of residual light sealed within.
“Don’t touch it.”
In the next second, she’s already at my side—fast as a blade of wind.
“Do you want it to remember you?”
“I just wanted to—”
“To know the truth?” She lets out a cold laugh. “The truth bites.”
She yanks me away from the line. The cold retreats at once, like a tide pulling back.
Lucia’s face has gone pale. “You almost triggered an echo… you would’ve been marked!”
“Marked?”
“Don’t ask.”
Her tone shuts the door outright. Not impatience—restraint pressed down over something burning.
“Let’s go. Back to the inn.”
We rush out of the alley. Snow and fog slam into us, and only then do I realize my back is soaked with sweat.
Lucia supports me the whole way, her voice still trembling. “Stop pushing yourself… you’re not like her.”
“Then what is she like?”
Alicia doesn’t turn back. She only leaves behind one sentence: “Someone who’s walked too long.”
The inn’s firelight wraps around us again. The sound of the bolt sliding into place feels like finally sealing danger outside.
